recipes.name: Spicy Papaya Salad with Seared Sirloin
directions: Step 1: Season the sirloin steak with salt, ground black pepper, and 1/2 tablespoon of olive oil. Sear the steak in a pan over medium-high heat until it reaches your desired level of doneness. Let it rest for a few minutes, then thinly slice against the grain and set aside.

Step 2: In a small bowl, whisk together the minced garlic, minced red chili pepper, fish sauce, soy sauce, lime juice, palm sugar, and 3 tablespoons of olive oil to make the dressing. Stir in the sliced cilantro.
Step 3: Arrange the shredded papaya, halved cherry tomatoes, and sliced sirloin on a serving platter. Drizzle the dressing over the salad and top with the roasted peanuts. Serve immediately.
recipes.image_prompt: Capture a vibrant, close-up shot of Spicy Papaya Salad with Seared Sirloin. Style the shredded papaya salad with halved cherry tomatoes, roasted peanuts, and chili flakes on a dark slate plate. Position the perfectly seared sirloin, glistening with juices, atop the salad. Use a shallow depth of field, focusing on the sirloin's texture. Incorporate dark, moody lighting with a subtle backlight to highlight the vibrant colors and textures. Garnish with fresh cilantro sprigs and lime wedges. Shoot from a slightly overhead angle to showcase the dish's layered components.

video_script.title: Spicy Papaya Salad with Seared Sirloin
video_script.description: Learn to make this vibrant and flavorful Thai-inspired salad with tender seared sirloin, crunchy papaya, and a spicy kick!

scenes.image_prompt: Close-up shot of a finished spicy papaya salad with seared sirloin. Show the vibrant colors of the salad, the glistening sirloin slices, and the sprinkle of roasted peanuts. The salad is arranged beautifully on a platter.
scenes.voice_over: Get ready to tantalize your taste buds with this Spicy Papaya Salad and perfectly seared sirloin steak!

scenes.image_prompt: Display all ingredients for the recipe neatly arranged on a wooden table: sirloin steak, ground black pepper, olive oil, shredded papaya, cherry tomatoes, roasted peanuts, salt, garlic, red chili pepper, fish sauce, soy sauce, lime juice, palm sugar, and cilantro.
scenes.voice_over: Here's what you'll need for this zesty creation.

scenes.image_prompt: Close-up of the sirloin being seasoned with salt, pepper, and olive oil.
scenes.voice_over: Season your sirloin generously with salt, pepper, and olive oil. Sear in a pan over medium-high heat for about 3-4 minutes per side for medium-rare, or until your desired doneness.

scenes.image_prompt: Sliced sirloin steak resting on a cutting board.
scenes.voice_over: Let the steak rest for a few minutes before slicing it thinly against the grain. This will help it retain its juiciness.

scenes.image_prompt: Show the ingredients for the dressing in a small bowl: minced garlic, minced chili, fish sauce, soy sauce, lime juice, palm sugar, olive oil, and cilantro. Then, show whisking the ingredients together.
scenes.voice_over: Whisk together the minced garlic, chili, fish sauce, soy sauce, lime juice, palm sugar, olive oil, and cilantro in a small bowl to create a vibrant and flavorful dressing.

scenes.image_prompt: Show the shredded papaya, halved cherry tomatoes, and sliced sirloin beautifully arranged on a serving platter.
scenes.voice_over: Now, artfully arrange the shredded papaya, halved cherry tomatoes, and sliced sirloin on your serving platter. This salad is all about textures and colors.

scenes.image_prompt: Show the dressing being drizzled over the salad and the roasted peanuts being sprinkled on top. Focus on the even distribution of the dressing and peanuts.
scenes.voice_over: Drizzle the dressing generously over the salad, ensuring everything is coated. Finish by sprinkling those crunchy roasted peanuts on top.

scenes.image_prompt: Close-up shot of the finished Spicy Papaya Salad with Seared Sirloin. Garnish with a lime wedge and some extra cilantro. Show it being served with chopsticks.
scenes.voice_over: Serve this Spicy Papaya Salad with Seared Sirloin immediately. It's a fantastic dish for lunch or a light dinner. Enjoy!

cooking_tips: For a spicier salad, add more chili pepper to the dressing.
If you don't have palm sugar, you can substitute brown sugar or granulated sugar.
Make sure the papaya is unripe for the best texture and flavor.
